direction.raw_text: Maybe I already know. The defense has given way and there is no mirth in the questions and answers now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter? What are you hinting at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Is there something to hint at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe a lot. Or maybe you just think there's a lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I do. Maybe there's been a long line of beach parties -- 57.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be crazy -- !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I? Listen, baby, maybe not here. But what about when you and Holmes were at Fort Bliss? Karen flings off the blankets, snatches her dress, stands up, raging. She speaks as she pulls the dress over her head, wriggles into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to go and forget you were a man -- with the same rotten filthy mind the rest of them have. For a minute I had to convince myself you were different -- WARDEN Only it's true, ain't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it's true! A part of it, some small part of whatever sewage you've been listening to. Some day perhaps you'll get all the story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All what story?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're getting to sound so much like a typical male. So you just sweat it out like a typical male. She starts toward the rocks at the end of the beach, walking fast, then almost running. Warden runs after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BEACH NEAR PATH UP ROCKS as Warden catches up with Karen. He grasps her arm roughly, hauls her down onto the sand. He stares at her bitterly, waiting f or her to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. I've never told it to anyone before. But I think now is the time. I'll tell you the whole bloody messy thing. You can take it back to the barracks with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She speaks rapidly, pouring it out in bursts. For much of the story her face is in shadow, as if a cloud is passing across the moon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd been married to Captain Dana E. Holmes two years. Only he was a First Lieutenant then. Back at Fort Bliss. We lived right on a little lake where we could fish and swim and be alone, our 'dream cottage'... I'm sure you must be able to picture it. It was off on a back road, four miles from the highway. Two miles from a neighbor and a telephone.... (pauses, then rushes on) I hadn't been married long when I knew my husband was stepping out on me. But -- you get used to that. Your mother tells you that it's life, that i t happens to a lot of women. Of course, she doesn't tell you until after it happens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FEATURING WARDEN reacting with fury toward Holmes, compassion for Karen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, by that time, you're pregnant. And at least you've something else to hope for. I think I was almost happy that night the pains began. Even though they were weeks too early, a whole month too early. I remember Dana was putting on that dapper silk gabardine uniform he used to wear. He was going to an officer's 'seminar.' He was kidding me about false labor. I didn't think it was humorous. I told him to get home early, to bring the doctor with him. He smiled tenderly and told me about the psychic reactions of women to pregnancy. But never fear, he'd be back early. And maybe he would have... if the 'seminar' hadn't been with the hat-check girl in one of the night clubs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was only a little drunk when he came in... at five a.m. He looked alarmed when he saw me. I guess it was because of my screams. I was lying there on the floor, you see -- No, don't say anything. I'm not finished yet. Of course, the baby was dead. It was a boy. But they worked over me at the hospital and fixed me up fine. They even took my appendix out, too. They threw that in free. It was all fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen. Listen. Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, of course, one more thing no more children. Do you know what that means? You're not a woman. You're not anything. You're a gutted shell... Sure, I went out with some of the men after that. A few months of it. I'd been made dirty and I wanted to be clean. You can see that, can't you?... Anyway, I got my revenge on Dana. I kept on living with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hateful, miserable -- KAREN You hunt so hungrily for love... love, if you can find it, you think, might give things meaning again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listens Listen to me -- KAREN All right. I'm listening. Warden shakes his head, inarticulate with his rage and love. Karen moves closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Until I met you I didn't think it was possible, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over shot soft strumming guitars and two voices singing a quiet blues. There are scattered groups,about fifteen men in all -- playing pool, ping-pong, reading, writing letters, talking. CAMERA REACHES PRIVATE SAL ANDERSON and Friday Clark, playing the guitars and singing. Clark plays only passably, but Anderson is highly accomplished, effortlessly sounding off chord progressions in diminished minors. Friday, the bugler, is about twenty-four, with shy, trusting eyes. Anderson is the same age, also quiet, non-aggressive. CAMERA CONTINUES PANNING, PASSES a soldier reading a newspaper who shakes his head and mutters, "... ain't it terrible about Lou Gehrig dyin...", then MOVES IN to HOLD on a group at a window seat, bulling. Prew is stretched out wearily, looks as if he's been through another recent dose of The Treatment. Maggio perches in the frame of the window like an aggressive robin. Treadwell slouches at the end of the seat. Pete Karelsen is in a chair nearby, reading a magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Ah'm in the Army because Ah can live better on the Inside than on the Outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It ain't the reason I'm in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now he's gonna give us that snow about bein a Thirty-Year Man again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Look at Karelsen there. Only seven years more for rockin chair money. Karelsen hears his name, looks over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KARELSEN
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: so we see he's reading a full-page advertisement featuring a girl in a revealing negligee. He is feeling sorry for him;elf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Profession wears you down, though, young man. Down thin like a knife what's been honed and honed. All that good steel just rubbed away... He turns back sadly to study the figure of the girl.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ANDERSON AND CLARK OTHERS IN B

direction.raw_text: FEATURING ANDERSON AND CLARK OTHERS IN B.G. Anderson peels off a flourish as he and Clark end their song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man, that's blues! Where'd you drag that one up Prom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, just stumbled on it. He strums aimlessly again. Prew and Treadwell come over to listen, prop themselves on chairs. During following, several others stroll over and a soldier writing at a desk nearby stops, turns to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW warmed by the friendliness of the music and the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They got Truckdrivers' Blues... Sharecroppers' Blues... Bricklayers' Blues... We oughta have a Soljers' Blues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GROUP as Anderson repeats a theme he has happened on. It has a haunting melody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, look... I betcha we could make one out of what you just played. Do that again. Anderson repeats the melody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could bring it down to a third line major ending... Regular twelve bars blues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet I got two hundred blues records back home. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there ain't one could touch that. And that includes Saint Louis. And it could be ours... The men wear pleased smiles, delighted by the idea of possessing something quite rare and truly their own. Prew flips his cigarette into a can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it. We call it the `Re- enlistment Blues'! There is a chorus of approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lookit, w e could start it with the guy getting discharged. (reaches over to desk) Hey, fella, can I use this? The soldier at the desk nods, and Prew takes his pencil and paper. He writes down the words of the song as they are composed during following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's this? 'Got paid out on Monday... Not a dog soljer no more... They gimme all that money....' He stops, stuck. Anderson plays the melody and Prew sings the words to this point. Friday Clark chimes in suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'They gimme all that money... So much my pockets is sore...' They laugh. Anderson sings. Prew writes furiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'More dough than I can use. Re- enlistment Blues...'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson plays a series of chords, then repeats the last two lines as the whole group joins in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'More dough than I can use. Re- enlistment Blues...'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raucous, hammering music sweeps away the melancholy blues. On the floor of the gym Dhom is punching the bag. In a corner of the raised ring Ike Galovitch is skipping rope. In the center of the ring Thornhill and Henderson are sparring. Holmes hovers beside them, issuing instructions in a strident voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW He is in fatigue clothes, on his knees, scrubbing the floor. There is an expression of stubborn hate on his face. Above his head in the shot are Galovitch's feet jumping the rope. In b.g. of shot is Wilson, seated near ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some day you get sense in your dumb head, Prewitt, you be up here instead down there! A fine spray of spit accompanies the words and showers over Prew but he keeps about his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still makin out you like it, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are two water buckets near Galovitch. He skips near one of them, kicks it. The bucket falls on its side and dirty water spills over the ring and down onto Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clean up dis mess, Prewitt! Prew gets to his feet. Galovitch resumes skipping rope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And look a life, hurry it up. You on fatigue detail, not vacation. Prew climbs into the ring, gets on his knees, starts to swab up the canvas. He is nearly finished when Galovitch "accidentally" kicks over the second bucket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clean up, Prewitt! Prew suddenly stands, no longer able to contain his rage. He throws his sponge and scrubbing brush on the ring floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clean it up yourself!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? What!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me -- rub your own nose in it a while!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What! Prew starts out of the ring. Holmes intercepts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with you, Prewitt? You know better than to talk back to a non-commissioned officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. But I have never liked being spit at, sir. Even by a non- commissioned officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you owe Sergeant Galovitch an apology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think I owe him no apology. In fact, I think one's owed to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant Galovitch, take this man to the barracks and have him roll a full field pack, extra shoes, helmet and all, and then take a bicycle and hike him up to Kole- Kole Pass and back. And see that he hikes all the way. And when he gets back, bring him to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Sirr. Prew climbs out of the ring, Galovitch following him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 65. Par below in the shot are Prew, hiking, and Galovitch, riding behind him on the bicycle. The dirt road is steep and the sun pours down, steaming hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW AND GALOVITCH Prew is hunched under the seventy-pound pack as he plods along. He is sweat-soaked, puffing, dog-weary. Galovitch's bicycle is just behind him; he runs the wheels up on Prew's heels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move along. You not half way yet. Three more miles to top. A jeep rounds a curve a couple of hundred yards above and moves down the road. It slows its speed and pulls up when it nears Prew and Galovitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jeep is driven by an enlisted man. Sitting next to him is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Galovitch hops off the bike and he and Prew snap to attention. General Slater leans out of the vehicle. He seems puzzled and interested by the odd sight of the two men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At ease. Where're you men headed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Top of pass, Sir. This man insubordinate. The Captain is teaching him lesson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your outfit, Sergeant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Company G, 219th, Sir. The General, still frowning slightly, nods. He signals his driver to move on. The jeep starts down the road. Galovitch gets on his bicycle. Prew starts hiking again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prew and Galovitch are standing in front of the Captain's desk. Prew is at attention, the heavy pack on his back; his face is drawn and tired; his clothes are plastered to him. He has regained his old expressionless look. Warden has swung his chair around and is surveying the scene. Holmes looks
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Prew up and down, half-smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I take it you're ready to apologize to Sergeant Galovitch now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir, I'm not. Holmes' face sets; he jerks his head toward the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take him back up there again, Galovitch. He hasn't had enough yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods unhappily, sick of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, air. Prew about-faces and goes out. Galovitch follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FEATURING WARDEN HOLMES IN B.G. Warden watches Prew go out, then looks toward Holmes whose back is to him. Disgust is reflected on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN AND HOLMES Holmes slams his fist on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1 know that kind of man! He's an againster. A bitter-ender. You can't be decent to a man like that. You have to tame him, like an animal! (TO WARDEN) Warden, I want you to prepare court martial papers. Insubordination and insolence to an officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Warden swings around to his own desk. He thinks for several moments, tries to sound quite casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too bad you got to lose a middleweight like that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Do you see any other way of breaking him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... But even if he only gets three months, he'll still be in the Stockade when the boxing finals come up. He looks over at Holmes, sees him scowling, weakening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about just giving him a good stiff Compny punishment for now? Holmes ponders the situation unhappily, rubs his hand over his face,. shakes his head as if the whole thing is too much for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, all right. But throw the book at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleased but impassive) Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN SHOOTING INTO SMALL MIRROR He is trimming his moustache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sick of it! They ain't got no right to keep breakin it off in that kid! Sooner later Holmes is going to hound him right into the Stockade!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karelsen across the room, undressing tiredly, achingly. Warden is sharp and blustering, using Karelsen as an escape valve. During following he goes to his footlocker, opens it, takes out whisky bottle, drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm through! I'm turnin in my stripes. I mean it, Pete. I could transfer out tomorrow. In Grade -- get that? To half a dozen Compnys in this Regmint!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, sure. I could be Chief of Staff, too, except I can't stand leaving all my old buddies. Karelsen is naked now except for a bath towel knotted around his middle. He slips his feet into Japanese-style, wooden clogs, starts slowly for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you going, Little Sir Echo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To take my stinkin shower, if the First Sergeant's got no objections. Where'd you think? To the movies in this towel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry up. Let's go over to Choy's for some beer and tear up all the tables and chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles, moves faster) Okay, Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OLD CHOY An aged Chinese, at least seventy-five, OLD CHOY has a long white beard and wears a black skull cap and an embroidered robe. He is motionless, surveying the pandemonium which we hear over shot: the sounds of men laughing, talking and shouting blend with jukebox music blasting Chattanooga, Choo Choo. YOUNG CHOP, Old Choy's son, passes; he is thirty, white- aproned, bustling, Americanized. CAMERA PANS WITH him,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the small beer-house; it has unpainted cement walls and a cement floor; the only thing that might be called decorative is the jukebox. The place is crowded with men from Schofield, a raucous assemblage; everyone is drinking beer and the smoke hangs in thick layers. At a table near the door sit Prew, Maggio, Clark, Anderson, Treadwell and Mazzioli. At a corner table behind a forest of beer bottles and cans are Warden, Stark, Karelsen and Chief Choate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN'S TABLE 69.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... China's the place. Your money's worth ten, twelves times as much. I'm gunna ship over soon as my time's up in this pineapple Army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pinching beer off his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Canal Zone for me. This girl down there. She was a planter's daughter, see. She lived a very sheltered life. A very moral young lady, Milt. I took her out to a high class dinner and then dancing. It was a great shock to her to learn about life. But she took it well. She got to like me very much after that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last time I heard it you told it different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what did you expect? I was in a different mood, then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW'S TABLE Maggio, Anderson and Treadwell are comparing snapshots from home, spreading them out on the table. Mazzioli is talking to Prew with great earnestness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... it's in regulations. You've got a right to complain. You've got a right to take your case to the Inspector General. Any soldier has, even a plain dogface.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it. I'm not complainin to nobody. They ain't goin to get the satisfaction of seein me squirm. Clark begins to play the bugle softly along with the jukebox music, noodling an uninspired obligato.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing to pictures) ... believe it nor not, this is one soljer who's got a family -- look, fifteen of 'em. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See that old man with the handlebars? (PROUDLY) Mr. Maggio is my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, Prew. I guess I ought not to tell you but --. Warden hasn't had you on KP much lately, has he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only my reglar turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well -- I was working in the Orderly Room this afternoon and I heard the Captain telling Warden you're to pull KP every weekend from now on. You know what that means -- you can' t even go into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whadda they want? They done everything, now they look me in a box! What else they gonna try? Clark hits a sour note an the bugle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you gonna learn to play a bugle!? In overwhelming, uncontrollable protest, Prew slaps the bugle away from Clark's mouth. In one motion he wipes the mouthpiece on his sleeve, raises it to his lips and blows his own wild, violent obligato to the jukebox music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CHOY'S as Prew plays on, the bugle's pure tone pealing through the room. Everyone puts down his beer, stops talking and turns toward Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN reacting. He frowns, moved by the cry behind the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW'S TABLE FEATURING MAGGIO as he watches and listens, an exultation for his friend nakedly revealed on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW'S TABLE FEATURING PREW Hitting an almost impossibly high note, he stops as suddenly as he has begun. He has played perhaps fifteen seconds in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . all. He puts the bugle down on the table, embarrassed now, the violence gone, some of the wrath unloaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT DOOR The room is quiet for several moments, except for the continuing jukebox music, which sounds pale and thin now. Fatso Judson strolls in, stands at the door. Some of the men see him, but no one greets him. Fatso threads his way between tables as the room slowly begins to return to normal and the men turn back to their beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW'S TABLE as Fatso passes. He stops, leans over Anderson's shoulder to look at the snapshots on the table. He points to one picture, a pretty young girl of about fifteen, posing Hollywoodishly in a bathing suit, cracks his knuckles loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that? Who's that dame?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My sister. Fatso whistles. He picks up the photograph, stares at it, whistles again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever! Say, she's a real good piece of whistle bait! I'd sure like to get my mitts around her. He laughs complacently at his own wit, tosses the picture on the table, starts to move on, Maggio rises, picks up the heavy wooden stool he's been sitting on and smashes it down on Fatso's head with all his strength,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as again the laughing and shouting in the room stops abruptly. Fatso reels a little with the terrible blow but does not go down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, holy -- I You hit met You hit me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet your life. (RAISES STOOL) And about to do it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still blinking from the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?! But what for? That's no way to fight! (reaches hand to head, brings away blood) Why, you dirty yellow sneaking -- Wop! You yellow little Wop! If that's the way you want to play! With his last sentence, Fatso whips out a knife and snaps open the blade. The blade is at least five inches long. It glints evilly as he raises it. There is a concerted whisking intake of breath from the room. Murder is clear on Fat sots face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NEAR PREW'S TABLE (EXCLUDING WARDEN) Maggio, holding the stool high, backs up a few feet as Fatso advances toward him. Men sprawl away from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, it you want to fight, fight with fists. Take it outsides There is a murmur of agreement from the crowd. A couple of men are about to rise. Fatso whirls toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna cut this little Wop's heart out. Anybody steps in here, I give it to him first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OLD CHOY AND YOUNG CHOY side by side. Old Choy watches, immobile, his slit eyes almost closed. Young Choy is shaking with fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FATSO AND MAGGIO Fatso turns toward Maggio, who circles back around the table as the other stalks him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (scared but brave; shouts) I'm gunna de-brain ya, Fatso! One step closer an I'm gunna kill ya! Fatso has his knife poised at his shoulder, ready to strike. Warden comes into shot suddenly. He brandishes a beer bottle wildly, looks like an avenging spirit of authority.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's gunna do nothin! Anybody's killin anybody around here, it'll be me! Warden snatches another beer bottle from a table, now has one in each hand. He steps between Fatso and Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look outs here, Warden. This a private affair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it ain't! This man's in my Compny an I'm responsible for him. And you ain't makin two weeks extra paper work for me by killin him. Nor him you. Put that knife down! He smashes the neck off one of the beer bottles, points the wagged edge at Fatso, roars:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put it down! Fatso slowly lowers the knife to his waist, but keeps it pointed towards Maggio and Warden. Warden deliberately turns his back to Fatso, spits his words at Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Killer! You unweaned punk& Come on, you want some killing, come on! (whirls on Fatso) Come on, barrelbelly. Ain't you comin? Neither Fatso nor Maggio moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with mammoth contempt) Killers! You'll get plenty of killing, all right. More than you got the stomach for. You'll be in a war one of these days. When you feel that lead from a sniper's rifle hit you between the eyes, come and tell me how you like it. Killers! (turns to Maggio) Now put down that chair. Maggio puts down the stool. Warden turns to Fatso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throw that knife on the floor. Fatso drops the knife. It clatters on the floor. There is another audible whoosh of breath from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost scared there wasn't anybody going to stop you for a minute, weren't you? (finally lowers his voice) Is there any other little things you punks'd like me to take care of for you? He drops the beer bottles on a nearby table, strides to his own table. The room settles back, still hushed. Warden has broken the mood of certain death, but Fatso, still facing Maggio, bites off his words with sadistic, ominous venom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tough monkey. Hard sister. Guys like you get to the Stockade sooner later. One day you walk in there I'll be waitin. I'll show you a coupla things. He walks away, drops into a stool at the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN'S TABLE Warden stands beside the table, watching. He seems satisfied as Fatso moves away from Maggio. Still standing, he raises his half-filled bottle of beer, drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW'S TABLE Maggio drops onto the stool, sidles it over to the table. He half-whispers to Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I made a mistake I guess, but I don't see how I could of done anything else, after that big stoop said a thing like that. Prew leans over and picks the knife off the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you your mistake. You didn't hit him hard enough to put him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hit him hard as I could. His head must be solid ivory. In b.g. Warden puts down the beer bottle and stalks towards the door. Maggio and Prew turn to watch him pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, I'm glad he stopped it. He's a good man, you know it? As if on impulse, Prew rises and follows Warden out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Prew carves out. Choy's is on a wide road across from the entrance to the Post. Prew looks around for Warden, sees him off to one side. CAMERA MOVES WITH Prew as he goes over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN leaning against the building, undergoing a delayed reaction to the fierce moment in Choy's. He is white-faced, sweating heavily. He looks as if he's going to be sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW astonished yet appreciative that under Warden's confidence and control in Choy's there has been a human frailty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... That was a near thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yeah. Prew holds out Fatso's knife. Warden is beginning to get control of himself; he manages a weak smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You keep it, kid. Keep it for a souvenir. Prew puts the knife in his pocket. They stare at one another a few moments, each inarticulate, each wanting to express some deep emotion of respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ain't enjoying life much, are you, kid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can kill you but they can't eat you, Top. Warden studies Prew thoughtfully. Prew turns to go back into Choy's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prewitt. Prew stops, turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you stand a weekend pass? Prew stares at him for a second, incredulously, unable to find his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought -- WARDEN You thought what, kid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about Dynamite?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave Dynamite to me. He signs most anything I put in front of him `thout readies it. Though Prew is overjoyed he is somehow unable to say "thanks"; Warden grins broadly at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear you gone dippy over some dame you met at the New Congress Club. He slaps Prew on the shoulder roughly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you say her name was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lorene...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Warden walks off across the street. Prew stares after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW AND LORENE Lorene is covering Prew with sand and has him almost completely buried. Only his face remains uncovered. He is griming up at her. She seems thoughtful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Lorene... She throws a towel over his face. He chuckles under it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name's Alma. The chuckle from under the towel dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alma Schmidt... There is a sound as of strangling from under the towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Kipfer picked Lorene out of a perfume ad. She thought it sounded French... Lorene whisks the towel away. Prew's face is comic in its surprise and chagrin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT BAR ALMA AND PREW (NOTE: From this point on "ALMA" will be used instead of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .") A fashionable Waikiki night spot. An orchestra in b.g, is playing "Someone's Rocking My Dream Boat." Alma and Prew are seated at the bar. She is dressed modestly and becomingly, might well be taken as a society girl. Prew is wearing a civilian suit; he looks bound and choked in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alma... She smiles ruefully, realizes her real name has rubbed off some of the enchantment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, honest, I like it. Alma's a -- swell name. It was great you gettin away today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told Mrs. Kipfer I was sick. But I bet she doesn't believe it,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no tellin when I'll get into town next. The Warden gave me a break this time. But Holmes and those others, they got me on the edge. I just about went off the deep end the other day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must hate the Army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hate the Army...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Look what it's doing to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the Army that's doing it. It's Man. I love the Army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love it? Well, it sure doesn't love you in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you love something it doesn't mean they got to love you in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but a person can stand just so much from something -- PREW No! A man loves a thing, he's gotta be grateful. (pauses, gropes for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I left home when I was seventeen. Both my folks was dead, then. I bummed around. I got all sorts of jobs. I rode the rods. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I landed in jails. I didn't belong nowhere. Until I entered the Profession. She frowns, not understanding the last word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Army. I enlisted at Fort Myer and I learned how to box and I learned how to play a bugle. I never had much call for the boxing - - but if it weren't for the Army I'd never of learned how to play a bugle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bugle? Prew nods. He takes the mouthpiece out of his pocket, shows it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the mouthpiece I used to play a Taps at Arlington. Alma takes the mouthpiece, looks it over, seems unimpressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as if saying "I was
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They picked me to play a Taps -- at Arlington Cemetery. She still looks dubious, hands the mouthpiece back. He tries desperately to communicate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. Think. You ever think how strange a tree would look to one who had never lived upon the earth? Well, somehow that's how I feel when I play a bugle... There is a boisterous shouting nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, citizen! I told ya I'd meet ya, dint I? They turn and ANGLE WIDENS to INCLUDE Maggio, who has just come up to the bar. He is in uniform. Prew is pleased to see him but also alarmed; there is something near-desperate under Maggio's drunkenness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you get a pass?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dint get no pass. I just took off. I meant to bring a girl with me but -- PREW You better get your tail back to the Post. Right away. Maggio shakes his head violently in the negative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm out for the night. I got a bellyfull. A nail, Prew. A stinkin nail. I'm thirsty for a nail. Prew gives him a cigarette. Maggio hops on an empty bar stool a few places removed from Prew and Alma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Climb up on my shoulders, Prew. You can see everythin from up here. (TO BARTENDER) A beer. A BEER!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT SIDE OF ROOM TWO MPs watching Maggio, attracted by his voice and behavior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT BAR FEATURING MAGGIO Maggio talks across others at the bar to Prew and Alma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I been in a crap game in the latrine. I win twenty bucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much did you lose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lose? Oh, lose. I lost twenty-seven bucks. (DEJECTEDLY) That's why I ain't got no girl. A tray on the bar contains olives, nuts and pretzels. Maggio snatches up two olives, shakes them in his fist beside his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! THE TERROR OF GIMBEL'S BASEMENT! COMIN OUT! SEV-EN! SEV- EN! SEV-EN! (rolls the olives out on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snake eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BARTENDER SEVERAL OTHERS AT BAR laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW AND ALMA Prew is increasingly concerned for Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like him, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's such a comical little guy and yet somehow he makes me always want to cry while I'm laughin at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AT BAR FEATURING MAGGIO finishing a long gulp of beer. He puts glass down on the bar, hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Royal Hawaiian's jist around the corner. That's where them movie stars stay. Rita Hayworth and Joan Blondell and Maureen O'Hara... You look like a movie star, Lorene... yes, you do... How long 'fore we get in the war, Prew?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe we won't get in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tha's what you say. He jumps off the bar stool suddenly, tears off his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hot in here. He throws tie on the bar, The Bartender starts to protest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swimming It's a great night for swimmin. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (kicks off shoes) Goin swimmin with a movie star... He is unbuttoning his shirt as he abruptly dashes away, People around are laughing at him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ALMA AND PREW as Prew watches Maggio rush out. He sees something else o.s, which worries him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two MPs cross toward direction Maggio has taken. They are obviously going after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ALMA AND PREW Alma follows Prew's troubled look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better go look out for him, Prew glances at her gratefully, then slips off his stool. He picks up Maggio's tie and shoes and hurries out after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tall pale royal palms contrast with thick dark plants and bushes. An ornamental lamppost alongside a walking path a little distance away. Prew comes into shot cautiously, carrying Maggio's tie and shoes. He moves quickly, bends over. CAMERA PANS AND MOVES IN and we see it is Maggio's shirt and trousers which Prew has discovered on the ground. He looks at them wryly, picks them up, moves on.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: AND LAMPPOST WITH BENCH NEAR IT IN B

direction.raw_text: PREW IN F.G. AND LAMPPOST WITH BENCH NEAR IT IN B.G. Prew, carrying Maggio's clothes, stops as he sees what looks like a shadow lying across the bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that you, Angelo? The shadow does not move. Prew approaches the bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MAGGIO AND PREW Maggio is stretched out on the bench, seems to be sleeping blissfully. He is clothed only in his shorts. Despite himself, Prew smiles. He shakes the reclining figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggio, you nut. Get up. Wake up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Maggio mumbles without opening his eyes or moving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir. I won't do it again. Just don't lock me up, sir. Honest, I won't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's your clothes. He throws the clothes on Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (opens his eyes) Well, give 'em back to the Indians. The Indians need clothes. All they wear is G strings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, are you drunk!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... maybe a movie star comes outs the hotel right now and picks us up and takes us back to the States in her private plane... and installs us in her private swimming pool -- Prew pulls Maggio off the bench and starts to drag him across the path away from the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy, Prew. You scrapin my tail on the sandy sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll get worse than that scraped - - Listen! The ominous sound of leggins brushing each other is heard, not far away. Prew looks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH BUSHES The two MPs are on the street just outside the grounds. They are still looking for Maggio, somewhat aimlessly now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MAGGIO AND PREW Prew whispers to Maggio as he pulls him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on before you're in trouble -- 84. Maggio pushes him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sick of its Can't a man get drunk? Can't a man do nothin? Can't a man put his lousy hands in his lousy pockets on a lousy street? A man gotta be hounded every minute of his life? I ain't gain to take its I ain't no cowards I ain't yellows I ain't no bums I ain't no scum! MPs! MPs! COME AND GET US!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you done it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: END OF PATH NEAR STREET The two MPs came running onto the path, spot Maggio and Prew about thirty yards away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PEW AND MAGGIO Maggio picks up his shoes, suddenly whips away from Prew and runs toward the MPs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NEAR MPs as they stop, surprised. Maggio is shouting, "Can't a man do nothin?!" as he hurls first one shoe, then the other, directly at the MPs. One MP is hit in the shoulder, staggers back. Maggio dashes between him and the second MP, but the latter reaches out and grabs him. Maggio wrenches loose but instead of running, suddenly wades in, arms swinging wildly. In a moment, he is hanging crab-like on the man's back. The first MP charges Maggio. Maggio grabs the second MP's club and hits the first MP over the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW Horrified, he starts toward the fracas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MAGGIO AND MPs IN F.G. PREW IN B.G. The second MP has managed to get out from under Maggio. He smashes his fist into Maggio's face as the latter continues to wield the club. Maggio sees Prew coming toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back! I'm handlin this! Take off! The first MP starts to intercept Prew. Maggio tackles him around the knees and brings him to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SECOND MP Club gone, his partner on the ground, the second UP fishes for his pistol, tugs to get it from the holster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This ain't your affair! Keep out of this!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW IN F.G. MPs AND MAGGIO IN B.G. Prew sees the second MP raise his pistol, point it toward him. CAMERA PANS WITH him as he turns quickly and dives headlong into bushes nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: him close to ground as he knees and elbows his way along deep into the bushes. He stops, breathing hard. The sound of the MPs fighting with Maggio can be heard, the ugly sound of fists and the uglier sound of clubs smashing bone and flesh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (screaming, crazed) Come on. Is that the best you can do? I bet you eat Wheaties, don't you? Come on... You can't even knock me out -- no matter -- Maggio's voice stops suddenly. CAMERA MOVES TO CLOSEUP of Prew on the ground, his face contorted. The voices of the MPs are heard now, panting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder what was wrong with this guy. He must be same kind of madman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, let"s get him into a wagon. A convulsive sob escapes Prew as his head drops in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ORDERLY ROOM- DAY MEDIUM SHOT PEEN WARDEN MAZZIOLI Warden is pinning some notices on a bulletin board. Prew sits on the bench against the wall, miserable, elbows on knees, chin in hand. There is a quiet tenseness in the room. Warden looks over at Prew, turns back to the bulletin board. Mazzioli gets up from his desk, wanders aimlessly to a window. The screen door slams and Leva enters, eating a candy bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any word on Maggio's Court Martial?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's on right now. At Headquarters. Lava sits on the bench beside Prew, shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll get the Stockade sure. The others tense at the word "Stockade," glare at Leva as if he had no right to mention it. Their fear of the place, now that it is imminent even for another soldier, is shown on their faces. There is a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he won't get it. All he did was get drunk and run wild. That's a soldier's nature. It's almost his sacred duty once in a while. There is another pause. Warden barks suddenly, fiercely, at Leva.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you hangin around here for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't a man rest himself for a min--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What man? I can't stand to see people restin themselves. I'm eccentric. If you ain't got no work maybe I can scare you up some. Mumbling, Leva rises and goes out. Warden goes over to Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whyn't you go on over to the Day Room, shoot a little pool? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll let you know when the word comes through. Prew looks up, nods, rises. He is half-way to the door when the phone at the Clerk's desk rings. Prew turns. Mazzioli stares at the phone as if afraid to touch it. Warden goes over, answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Compny G, First Sergeant Warden speaking... Yes, sir... Yes, sir, I will... I'll have his things in order... Yes, sir. Warden puts down phone. He looks at the waiting men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He got it. Six months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prew and a group of G Company men, including Sergeants Dhom, Thornhill and Henderson, are on the steps and porch as a Reconnaissance car pulls up and halts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: RECONNAISSANCE CAR Maggio sits between the driver and another MP, both armed. (NOTE: These are not the same MPs with whom he fought.) The G Company men cluster around the car, ad-libbing greetings, kidding Maggio, bucking him up. Even the Sergeants join in this; nobody likes to see a man on his way to the Stockade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, men! Who's got the beer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Brownie. Whatever you say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the Driver gets out of the car and goes to pick up Maggio's stacked barracks bag on the porch. Prew moves up close to Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Angelo. It's my fault. I SHOULDA -- 88.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You crazy. You -- PREW I shoulda stopped you somehow -- MAGGIO It was all my party. Don't worry about it. (pronounces "e" as in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyhow, I'm gunna e-scape. If Gimbel's basement couldn't hold me, neither can no lousy Stockade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard him say SHUT UP!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles at the men) I'm a prisoner. And prisoners ain't allowed to talk. They allowed to breathe though. If they good, that is. During last speech the Driver returns, dumps the barracks bag in the car, and gets in. The motor starts. The men shout good- byes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW heartsick as he looks at Maggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the Recon pulls out and Maggio's last hearty shout drifts back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... e-scape to Mexico and become a cowboy!...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STOCKADE GATE- DAY SHOT as the Reconnaissance car drives through the chain-mesh gate. In the distance is the Stockade, a building that looks something like a country schoolhouse. Music sweeps up as the gate clangs shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggio walking across the yard flanked by the tall MPs. He looks around as if surveying the chances of escape. Music rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the MPs march Maggio up to a door and gesture him to enter alone. He goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CAMERA SHOOTS from behind a man seated at a desk. Prominent in shot is a wicked-looking chopped-off hoe handle lying on the desk. Maggio enters, recognizes the man. He walks, up to the desk, his face set in defiance. Music is rising in a fearful crescendo. CAMERA PANS just enough to REVEAL desk sign reading: "SERGEANT OF THE GUARD." The man stands up and the music stops abruptly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: REVEALING Fatso Judson as the man, on his face the same murderous expression as at Choy's. He cracks his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tough monkey.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: OFFICE OF SERGEANT OF THE GUARD

direction.raw_text: MAGGIO his eyes following a movement of Fatso's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FATSO Eyes on Maggio, his hand gropes on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FATSO'S HAND as it finds and tightens around the hoe handle. The music sweeps in abruptly.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A POKER BEING DRIVEN INTO FIRE

direction.raw_text: FLASH A POKER BEING DRIVEN INTO FIRE Music of preceding shot segues into an ancient, savage Hawaiian chant which continues through following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FLASH LONG-PRONGED FORK BEING DRIVEN INTO BELLY OF WHOLE ROAST PIG CLOSE SHOT FLASH LANG-BLADED CARVING KNIFE SLICING ROAST BEEF MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT STEAM RISING FROM BETWEEN HOT STONES OF FIRE FULL SHOT LUAU Shot covers the continuation of all the above activity. This is a native luau - definitely not for tourists. Shot includes long ditches, heated by red-hot stones and lined with layers of banana leaves, containing pig, chicken, rock crabs, fish... Pots of native stew... Bowls of exotic fruit... Peels of raw cane... Working over the food are the natives, many of the men stripped to the waist, the women arrayed in colorful Hawaiian costumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH BONFIRE HULA DANCERS A group of male dancers swaying with the insistent beat of a group of old Hawaiian instruments. This is far removed from the night club Hula. This is a thing of swift, agile angularity, primitive and powerful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SPECTATORS THROUGH BONFIRE At end of PAN, CAMERA REVEALS Warden and Karen in the group. They are the only whites in the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KAREN her face lit by the flames. She watches the dancing breathlessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The native instruments playing a thin, weird melody.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FLASHES TINY TOM TOM NOSE FLUTE GROUP OF MUSICIANS

direction.raw_text: HULA DANCERS The men laugh and grin as they dance, taunt and tease somebody o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SPECTATORS They shout and laugh and squeal with delight as they watch. It is Warden the dancers are teasing. Several of the dancers break out of the group, dance over to Warden, continue to prod him, apparently urging him to join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN protesting, joining in the laughter. Suddenly he kicks off his shoes, rolls his slacks up to his knees. He snatches a gardenia from the hair of a pretty Hawaiian girl next to him, sticks it over his ear, jumps into the firelight and dances with the others. The music comes up louder and faster as the spectators and dancers roar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DANCERS AND WARDEN They are all laughing as they dance, but as Warden moves with them it is apparent he is as good as any of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SPECTATORS nodding, pointing at Warden, their hilarious laughter fading to delighted smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KAREN astonished and thrilled at Warden's ability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN His laughter now also diminished to a happy grin as he dances. In all he dances about thirty seconds. Then he breaks out of the group and runs over to Karen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FEATURING KAREN AND WARDEN as the spectators and dancers shout their applause. Warden comes up to Karen and puts the gardenia in her hair. Karen is glowing, tingling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just love to shock people, don't you?! Where on earth did you learn to dance like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe it or not -- Chicago, Illinois. She flings her arms around him passionately. The onlookers howl with approval and merriment. Between Karen and Warden and camera, an enormously fat Hawaiian woman pours water on the stones in one of the trench-ovens. A cloud of steam rises, hiding them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VALLEY
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a thousand feet into Palolo Valley. Bonfires and smoke rising from the floor of the valley. The thinnest carry of the ancient Hawaiian music. CAMERA PANS from precipice and INCLUDES Prew and Alma as they trudge into shot, climbing up the steep cliff road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: holding hands as they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I dint get to see you once in a while The Treatment would've cracked me long ago. Alma, fairly winded from the climb, smiles but doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could have taken a cab. Except I ain't got cab fare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just around the bend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they walk on around a bend in the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ALMA'S HOUSE MEDIUM SHOT The small house is perched precariously on the very edge of the cliff. Alma and Prew come around the bend, come up to the door, Prew marvelling at the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This other girl and I were lucky to rent it. (PROUDLY) It's a very fashionable district. She hands Prew her key. As he is unlocking the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get an extra one made for you. Prew swings open the door and they go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prew stops on the threshold, stares at the room in happy amazement. It is large, smartly furnished. In the rear, glass doors lead to a porch. One of the panelled walls is filled with bookshelves, floor to ceiling. The bookshelves are filled with books. A hearty feminine voice calls "Hi!" from the kitchen, and as Prew and Alma come into the room,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enters from the kitchen. She is a very tall, very gay, good-looking girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Gorgette, my roommate. Gorgette, this is Prew. I told you about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mind me. I'm going out in a little while. Prew grins, can't keep his eyes off the astonishing books. Gorgette follows his glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I belong to the Book of the Month Club. I always take every book. That way I get all the dividends. She giggles and goes off to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She'll be great for Maggio when he gets out of the Stockade. He'll be crazy about her because she's so tall. Alma smiles, presses him into a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you just get comfortable and I'll make you a Martini and see what's to cook for dinner. She starts oft to kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. She turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is just like bein married, ain't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (over her shoulder as she exits to kitchen) It's better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING through smoke rising from one of the trench-ovens. As it clears we see the enormous Hawaiian woman and one or two others cleaning up and putting out the remnants of the fires. The merrymakers and dancers have gone; the luau is over. In b.g., quite alone, are Warden and Karen, sitting on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . the trunk of a fallen palm tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KAREN AND WARDEN The abandoned gaiety of the earlier scene gone. They survey the emptiness. The fat Hawaiian woman comes near, rakes ashes over one of the dying fires. She speaks to Warden in Hawaiian. He answers her in the native tongue. The fat woman stares, shrugs, goes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did she say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She said it's over -- time to go
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Home... A beach, a car, a park... Warden puts his arm around her tenderly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll work out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can't go on like this much longer, Milt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. He rises, paces a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If there were only a way! Your lovin husband'd probly give you the divorce. But even if he didn't know what for, he'd never let me transfer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bucking up courage;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a way. I've been thinking about it. Warden looks at her apprehensively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got to become an officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're eligible for the extension course that came in with the draft. When you get your commission they'd ship you back to the States -- new officers aren't kept at posts where they've been enlisted men. Then -- WARDEN You sure made a thorough study of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I could divorce Dana and follow you and marry you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An officer! I've always hated officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a fine, intelligent point of view. Suppose I said I've always hated Sergeants. That would make a lot of sense, wouldn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WARDEN He sits, thinks it over unhappily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, suppose I did it. -- And don't think it's a cinch -- the exams are tough. Then you'd be getting your divorce here while I'm in the States. We'd be apart maybe six months! We'll probly be in the war by then -- TWO SHOT KAREN You can't be certain of that -- WARDEN (SNORTS) Put it down on your calendar. On October twenty-third, 1941, Milt Warden told you we'd be in the war in less than a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you tell the truth? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just don't want the responsibility. You're probably not even in love with me -- WARDEN You're crazy! I wish I wasn't in love with you. Maybe could enjoy life again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what's happened to you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you were honest at first -- WARDEN At first! You were tough and solid as a rock -- and now you're a whining crybaby -- He stops abruptly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so they were married and lived unhappily ever after. They are silent for several moments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never been so miserable in my life as I have since I met you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither have I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't trade a minute of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither would I. Warden rises and paces again. Suddenly he stops, turns, looks down at Karen, speaks in the same gloomy tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll probably make the lousiest officer they ever saw in this Army. A happy smile creeps over Karen's face. Despite himself, he begins to smile also.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll make a fine officer. A remarkable officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The porch is at the rear of the house, leading off from the living room. It is on the very edge of the cliff. Prew and Alma are dancing to the music of a portable victrola. It is playing "Why Don't We Do This More Often?" A table still contains the dinner plates. Prew's expression holds the wonder of a child at a magic show. He misses a step, stumbles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never caught on to dancing much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a very good dancer. The record ends and Alma goes to change it. CAMERA FOLLOWS Prew to the edge of the porch as he looks out over the view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: VIEW PROM PREW'S POV A magnificent panorama -- strings of lights in the valley and across on St. Louis Heights -- in the far distance the neon of Waikiki.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW working with his thoughts, afraid to broach them. He lights a cigarette, his fingers trembling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I been wanting to tell you a long time now -- (DEEP BREATH) I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ALMA looking through records for a new choice. She speaks quite conversationally, as if offered a pleasant compliment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's nice. Because I love you, too. She puts on a record -- "It All Comes Back To Me Now." It plays throughout the sequence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Alma comes over to Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean it. I need you. ALMA (AS BEFORE) I'm glad. Because I need you, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thirty-year man is movin all over, goin all the time. Up to now I never thought a thirty-year man had any business to think of gettin married. She stares at him, amazed, a touch angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a funny one, little Prew boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Must be the altitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very funny one that I cannot figure out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why's it funny if a guy wants to marry you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I'm a girl you met at the New Congress Club! And that's about two steps up from the pavement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay -- I'm a private no class dogface soljer. And the way most civilians look at it, that's two steps up from no thin. There is a silence. Alma is honestly distraught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Prew, Prew, I thought we were happy: Why do you want to spoil things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lissen, I ain't think in of now. But I got a plan cookin in my head. You want to go back to the States in a year. Well, you could stretch it some, make it two years. And I could swing a Sergeant's stripes -- If I were a non-com the Army'd let me pick my duty when I re-enlist. (lost in the picture of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there's some posts back in the States -- like Jefferson Barracks -- The married noncoms rate solid brick houses... with lawns with new- cut grass and walks with big old oak trees...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I know you've lost your mind! How do you expect to become a Sergeant under this Captain Holmes of yours? It's all you can do to keep out of the Stockade!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It I go out for boxin he'd send me to non-com school. The Regimental Championship is next month. I bet I could win the middleweight even without training. I used to be pretty good I could do it. Alma is deeply moved. She speaks gravely, sincerely, not at all immodestly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't think you should give in to The Treatment... even to marry me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This'd be worth it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prew -- it's true we love each other now. But back in America, it might be different... We might not even want each other...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. But that ain't the real reason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. It's not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the real reason you won't marry me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't marry you because I don't want to be the wife of a soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's the top I could ever do for you -- ALMA Because nobody's going to stop me from my plan. Nobody. Nothing. Because want to be proper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Proper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, proper. Respectable. Secure. In a year I'll have enough money saved. I'm going back to my home town in Oregon and I'm going to build a new home for my mother and myself and join the country club and take up golf. And then I'll meet the proper, man with the proper position. And I'll be a proper wife who can keep a proper home and raise proper children. And I will be happy because when you are proper you are safe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bitterly disappointed but
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got guts, Alma. I hope you pull it off. The victrola record ends. Alma turns away from Prew and goes to the victrola. Now that shots had her say with such certainty, she deflates. Except for the fact that she looks like a girl who never cries, she looks as if she might cry. She lifts the record off the turntable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I do mean it when I say I need you. Because I'm lonely. Sometimes I'm dreadfully lonely... You think I'm lying, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Nobody ever lies about being lonely... Alma puts the same record on again. Prew looks out over the beautiful view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HOLMES
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've known about it for a long time! I've sensed it. And I'm not going to ignore it any longer! I want to know where you met him and just who he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HOLMES AND KAREN at breakfast in a nook off the kitchen. Holmes is a mixture of petulance, anger and frustration. He doesn't touch his food, but occasionally takes a sip of coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I'm not going to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't keep a thing like this
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to hide anything. I'm just not going to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She applies herself to her food, anxious to drop the matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thing I know. I know it's a civilian. You'd be too discreet to pick an Army man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's any of your business who he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is my business! I'm your husband! What do you think a scandal would do to my chances for a promotion? So if you're thinking of a divorce, you can forget it! Karen stiffens. She struggles to maintain her self- possession. She manages it, keeps outwardly calm through the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now -- how does it feel to know you'll have to live with a horror like me the rest of your life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not very nice. But then there's the compensation of knowing you'll have to live with me the rest of your life. Her attitude makes Holmes progressively sorrier for himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with him as during following he rises, goes to stove, pours himself another cup of coffee. He spills a little and the liquid sizzles on the burner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know how a man feels about a thing like this. It breaks a man all up -- inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gander why men feel so differently about it than women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's -- it's just not the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with him as he returns to the table, decides to try another tack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you think I've done all I have...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done all what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tried to be a Company Commander when I hate it, worked my fool head off with this miserable boxing squad, tagged after the General whenever I could.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, for you and for me. For our home, that's why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always thought you did it because you wanted to get ahead. She finishes the last of her food, stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a lovely day out. I think I'll go for a walk. Holmes catches her wrist, stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm willing to forgive you. Tell me who he is. Make a clean breast of it. And I'll forgive you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder which is hurt more -- your pride or your curiosity? She disengages her wrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I'm ready to ask you for a divorce we can discuss it again. She goes to door to pantry, pauses there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And do eat your breakfast, Dana. It's getting cold. She goes out to pantry. We hear the sound of the door to rear porch opening and closing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HOLMES wretched, completely at a loss. He stares into space, then looks down at his food, picks up a fork and ruefully begins to eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LAWN Prew, on hands and knees, is on a weeding detail with three other men, one of them Sal Anderson. Another is PRIVATE NAIR, a tousle-headed, sentimental man we have not seen before. Sergeant Thornhill, in charge of the detail, lolls on the ground, his head propped against a tree, reading a comic book. Prew works his way over to Nair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just get out of the Stockade?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was rugged, sam. But I kept my mouth shut and watched my step and I wasn't in no trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see Maggio? Nair nods, tells his tale in half-humorous, half-reverent fashion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fatso's workin him over with a hoe handle. Places where it won't show mostly. You know, the back and the chest. The kidneys. Once in a while in the face. Know what Maggio does when that happens? Spits in Fatso's eye. (CHUCKLES) Oh, he's a hot one. Ain't he a hot one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a good boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Course, he throws up a little blood now and then. And he passes out a lot. But Fatso sure ain't reportin none of that. So there's no way they goin to find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't he go to the C.O.?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We tried to get him to. But he won't peep. He says he got a lot more scalp to lose first. That boy is about the hardest artery in the hospital. (with great sentiment) But he's got a heart just like a great big baby. Prew's face has been growing in fury. He pulls up a clump of sod, throws it down with all his might.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think he's gonna be all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your guess is worth mine, sam. Maybe he's crackin a little at that
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: cause after Fatso put him in the Hole -- that's what they call solitary -- a couple times he began talkin about how he's gonna e- scape. He said to tell you he'll look you up one of these nights. A shadow falls across the grass in front of Prew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CAMERA SHOOTING UP from near the ground, the ANGLE EXAGGERATING Galavitch's ungainly, ape-like figure. He looks down at Prew, full of venom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still on knees, eh, Prewitt? Well, boxing finals next month. December f if teen. You s till got time help us make champions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW FROM GALOVITCHE'S POV 106. Prew is at the breaking point. Controlling himself, he weeds around Galovitch's shadow. It moves in front of Prew again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are proud dis Compny to be or not? Bites de hand dat feeds it der shoot dogs for. Infortunately, ony dogs day are allowed to shoot, not men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GROUP The other men have stopped weeding, are looking over at Prew and Galovitch. Thornhill, in b.g., puts down the comic book and comes over to them during following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get outa my way, Ike. I ain't gonna move around you again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need better lesson than up to now. Maybe I give to you myself. Maybe right now. He steps on Prew's hand. As Prew jerks away from the heavy shoe Galovitch hauls him up by his fatigue shirt. Thornhill steps between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ey, leave him alone. `e's in my
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prew shoves Thornhill aside, cold decision in his eyes. He starts unbuttoning his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. It's gonna be your way. Galovitch rips off his shirt, bursting some of the buttons as he does. Stripped to the waist, his whole appearance seems to change; he looks as he did in the ring, a hard-muscled prize fighter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ey, wait a minute, you guys -- ! Prew is barely able to get out of his shirt before Galovitch charges him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S PREW AND GALOVITCH AND SPECTATORS During following men run from across the quadrangle and from out of the barracks to watch the affair, form a circle around
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . the fighters. Prew is a skillful boxer, moving around Galovitch quickly and cleverly. Galovitch is more lumbering but not awkward. His heavy blows stagger Prew several times. Prew drives his attack at his opponent's body. He never throws a punch at the other's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The head, Prew! Hit him in the head! The other men around shout similar advice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GALOVITCH puzzled by Prew's concentration on his body and by the shouts of the men. He seems to be wondering if Prew is pulling a trick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW A fear, not born of cowardice, is reflected on Prew's face as he sets himself, stares at Galovitch. He seems haunted by the memory of Dixie Wells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GALOVITCH'S EYES CLOSEUP PREW flinching without being hit. He seems mesmerized by the other's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GALOVITCH'S EYES MEDIUM SHOT PREW AND GALOVITCH fighting. Galovitch draws blood from a cut over Prew's eye. He is getting the better of the battle. In b.g. Thornhill breaks out of the crowd and runs across the quadrangle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BALDY DHOM AND SPECTATOR SPECTATOR I don't get it -- Why don't Prew go for the head?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He blinded a guy once. Must be scairt of the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PREW AND GALOVITCH as Galovitch batters Prew back against the crowd. A right to the temple sends him to his knees. He shakes his head a moment, gets up and goes into a clinch.
direction.name: direction
